user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_nonce_timestamp:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function get_nonce_timestamp:
#define NONCE_STD_LEN(digest_size) ((digest_size)*2+TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN)
...
#define MD5_DIGEST_SIZE (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*MD5_BYTES_IN_WORD)
...
#define MHD_MD5_SUPPORT 1
...
#define SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE
...
#define MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN (TIMESTAMP_BIN_SIZE*2)
...
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                       size_t maxlen,
                       uint64_t *out_val)
{
  size_t i;
  uint64_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT64_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 16)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 16;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  }

  if (i)
    *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only modification of a function parameter in the provided function is the assignment to the parameter noncelen. Other places do not modify parameters themselves: nonce is declared const char *const and is not assigned to (only used and pointer arithmetic in expressions), ptimestamp is a const pointer (uint64_t *const) and only the pointed-to object may be written by MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (writing through a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule), and the remaining statements only perform checks/returns. Therefore no other fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
